column1: Schismatrix (1985) by Bruce Sterling  - 236 pages  - rating: 2.5/10  All the elements of a brilliant science fiction novel are here. Sadly
column2: the author seems to have enormous problems in presenting them in a form the reader can enjoy.   His thoughts
column3: sentance and paragraph structure are frequently incomprehensible. His writing style is rambling and confused. Then suddenly
column4: 40 pages will go by which are interesting
column5: compelling and straightforward. It is as if the author wrote 80% of the novel while under the influence of a mind altering substance and the other 20% while sober.  Its tragic. I can see the man has skill. Unfortunately
column6: as a reader I am not willing to plow through the muck to get to the few moments of coherency.  If you like weird mind altering experiences you might enjoy this. I can see from the other reviews here that some people did. I have my suspicions that some of the reviews are intentionally misleading perhaps to promote sales or a new publishing.  If you enjoy interesting writing that flows with skill and allows the reader to enjoy the experience and the story without needing to decipher every second sentance then you should stick with authors like Orson Scott Card
column7: Greg Bear
column8: Gregory Benford
column9: or Fred Hoyle.  Claus Kellermann 2005 November 15 Sci_Fi_Researcher@yahoo.co

column1: I don't know what I expected
column2: but I didn't get it.  This novel has almost completely unexplained genetics and it needs more since the entire series hinges on us believing the genetics are possible.  I really don't believe the characters since the author doesn't take the trouble to develop them. She fails to explore Megan's psionic ability enough for us to care about why she's had to flee.  Nor do we have an explanation of the villain's motives. The plot seems to be a framework for some mediocre to okay erotica.  I'm slightly offended by the assumption that pheromones and hormones are all it takes to create a true mate for a human (and I include the Breeds).  These people don't know each other from Adam's off-ox but we're supposed to believe that they're mated for life--just because lions do.  Argh!  That makes the Breed the animals their detractors claim they are and reduces their genetically human lovers/mates to the same level. I hope that if Leigh continues the story
column3: we learn more about her characters and that she treats them more as feeling and thinking people. I'll sample the second one and if it's as underdeveloped as this one

column4: and I have managed to make an A in Biochemistry using this text; BUT it has everything to do with my ability to see the mistakes and editing errors in this edition!! It takes more time to figure out the wierd 5 graders level of programing that defines their "living graphs" than it takes to simply memorize word for word the page the equations come from in the text (if the equations are correct in the text in the first place!)  I am befuddled by the overwelmingly possitive reviews this second rate text has.  Did I some how get my hands on a first run of this text that should have been recalled like a lemon?  Every chaptor I take my text to my TA in the course and get an error clarified and she and I stand amazed at the amount of confusing errors in this text. I have since aquired a Voet text and look forward to reading it.       As a side note: the "study guide" to this text that I bought is more acuratly a "confuse you guide" written by monkeys who took on female human names.  They add things up incorrectly for God's sake!  Even though it will cost me more money I hope to God that my second semester of Biochem uses a different text book

column3: had several very distinct themes.  First
column4: the life of immigrants to New York City in the late 1800s was deplorable while housing for others was splendid.  "To-day three fourths of its people live in the tenements
column5: and the nineteenth century drift of the population to the cities is sending ever-increasing multitudes to crowd them" (Riis
column6: p. 6) Sections of tenement houses were divided by streets and alleys which divided the nationalities.  "As emigration from east to west follows the latitude
column7: so does the foreign influx in New York distribute itself along certain well-defined lines that waver and break only under the stronger pressure of a more gregarious race or the encroachments of inexorable business." (Riis
column8: p. 21)  Each nationality had some very distinct characteristics but they also had some very great differences as well. 	The next theme to emerge was that of work.  In some sections of the city

column101: endowing an entire legacy of its own." (Riis
column102: p. xiii)   	I believe the intent of the author was to simply bring a big picture view to narrow minded people.  He very much accomplished his purpose.  By using stories of families
column103: shocking details and everyday photographs of real people
column104: he was able to bring people to understand the reality of life in their own city and encourage them to help make changes.  It is often said that a picture is worth a thousand words
column105: and Riis is a prime example of this.  Not only are his accounts vivid and horrific
column106: but also his images leave nothing to the imagination.  The reader can not be left to imagining a rosier picture than was intended.  The illustrations both verbal and nonverbal are graphic and moving. 	The appropriate audience for this book would have to be very broadly
column108: adult citizens of our world.  The language used in this book can be
column110: a bit complicated to comprehend; this is why I believe it appropriate for mature adults.  I also believe very firmly that adults are sometimes the most difficult to convince to take action to help those less fortunate or those in need.  When we read real life accounts and see pictures of people just like us in deplorable conditions
column111: it is difficult for us to sit back and take no action.  I also believe it is important for citizens of our world to understand the underlying message of helping those less fortunate or those in need who may be right in our own back yard.  This book is a stunning example of one man giving factual accounts of events to produce concerned citizens ready to take action to improve conditions for fellow human beings.

column1: The theory's not bad

column4: Frapton can string together four or more sentences without self-contradiction.  HOWEVER.  The text here is so dry you'd almost rather eat it than read it.  Of interest  to students and serious scholars only.    Altogether too often Frampton lapses into what Robert Campbell calls archispeak
column5: an impenetrable wall of words borrowed from
column6: in this case for example
column7: phenomenologist philosophers.  I appreciate that a lot of thought went into the theory Frampton puts forward
column8: but this is not a theoretical text.  Frankly
column9: if you're authoring a history you ought to take a cue from Wittgenstein instead:  Speak clearly or not at all.  William Curtis's book is a much better history
column10: or at least a far more comprehensible one
column11: as is Spiro Kostof's more wide-ranging text.  This should be seen as a companion book to either of those
column12: a dense
column13: theoretical appendix
column14: perhaps.  Frampton's syntax is almost torturously overwrought
column15: a sure sign of someone who spends much more time thinking about and researching things than communicating them (and of a real dearth of good editors in the community).  There has got to be a middle ground between the coffee-table picture book and the kind of history aimed squarely at other writers of (and future writers of) architectural theory.  (And I say this as someone who routinely reads architectural theory and loves the Modernist movement.)  If only Reyner Banham were alive to write the reply (or even clarification) this book begs.  Come back to this book in grad school

column1: After completing my first year of law school
column2: I really wonder why so many professors use this textbook.  More than half the people I spoke with in my class thought the casebook's usability was poor or worse.   Property is not a difficult class
column3: aside from future estates and related issues (Rule Against Perpetuities).  The hardest thing about property is knowing the jurisdictional views on various aspects of property law
column4: and this casebook does only an OK job highlighting that.  It is basically a lot of memorization and the learning of that material could have been substantially aided by organizing the book differently.  Additionally
column5: many of its cases are not sufficiently edited
column6: thereby necessitating that one read through too much irrelevant information to get to the legal issue.  My other case books are much more balanced on this issue.    As a last note
column7: the production quality is lower than what I would expect for its price.  The paper chosen and the fair reproduction of what photos exist in the book contrast strongly with its price.    I suppose this sounds like a laundry list of complaints
column8: but the book compares poorly to my other casebooks
column9: simply stated

First be warned this product IS NOT WPA compatible!  Thus

The crux of how I got it to work is by using the router interface and entering the MAC addresses of the PS and computers in the network.  This is the golden key I searched for for hours trying all permutations of all the other settings in the router's and PS's web interfaces. column1: In the Cthulhu Mythos
column2: Clark Ashton Smith's The Book of Eibon ranks up there with Lovecraft's Necronomicon and Derleth's De Vermis Mysteriis; imaginary works of such soul-searing occult horror that readers put their own sanity and salvation at risk to peruse them. They form the basis of several story cycles and Mythos writers "quote" from them regularly. Chaosium's newest book in their Mythos series is an attempt to recreate The Book of Eibon using stories and poems written by Clark Ashton Smith
column3: Lin Carter
column4: Richard L. Tierney and others. At the bottom line
column5: the attempt is courageous
column6: but sadly
column7: a failure for several reasons:  First
column8: trying to create a legendary work of cosmic horror is impossible. Though many of the stories in the book are worthy of the Mythos label
column9: reality cannot compete with the imagination. I wanted a good read to keep me up at night
column10: not just a few hours of amusement.  Second
column11: there is too much of Lin Carter in the book. Like Derleth
column12: Carter was a rabid Mythos fan in love more with the idea than the atmosphere and thought it sufficient to make a story unearthly through simply listing a long litany of Mythos terms and names. Though some of Carter's stories are worth reading
column13: such as From The Archives of the Moon
column14: most are quickly forgettable.  Third
column15: Price
column16: who has edited most of the Chaosium works stumbles terribly as an editor. His introductions to the stories give too much away
column17: the worst example being his introduction to Lin Carter's In the Vale of Pnath where he reveals the ending
column18: ruining what is probably one of the few actually disturbing stories in the collection. Also unnecessary to the point of distraction are the innumerable comparisons of the literary creation of The Book of Eibon to the formation of the Old and New Testaments of the Bible. Yes
column19: Price is a seminary professor
column20: but not every reader is interested in lectures in the questionable science of Biblical Higher Criticism.  Readers who are collecting the Chaosium Mythos series will want to purchase The Book of Eibon and there are a few gems between its covers

column1: President James Monroe is cheifly remembered for his important role in defining the relationship of the United States with the rest of the globe with the Principles of 1823 (later known as the Monroe Doctrine).  No one would argue the significant impact of this contribution to the American political landscape.  However
column2: Gary Hart is unable in his portrait of the fifth President to enliven Monroe or to rescue him from relative obscurity.  He does make a noble attempt to present Monroe as the first "national security" president (a leader who never wavered in his commitment to keeping the United States prepared and safe).  Unfortunately
column3: Hart fails to create an engaging portrait.  At the end of the day
column4: despite Mr. Hart's effort
column5: Monroe cannot possibly command the interest and respect that a John Adams or a Thomas Jefferson would achieve.     In fact
column6: the man who was arguably greatly responsible for the Principles of 1823 and who served as Monroe's Secretary of State (who would himself become the sixth President) John Quincy Adams
column7: upstages James Monroe's bland personality.

column1: This may be the first time you hear me say this
column2: but Go Fish was too artistic and dated for my enjoyment.  I think that if I had seen this film when it was first released back in 1994 I would have been impressed.  This was a very avant-garde film that tried very hard to discuss an issue that was very "hush-hush" back in the early 90s.  Lesbians were very closeted back then and were not a major part of the culture norm as they are today (well
column3: as much as we recognize them today).  This makes for a very provocative film
column4: but it also makes for a very dated film.  This was my biggest issue with this film was that it nearly felt like a comedy instead of this symbolic struggle to pursue happiness like any heterosexual relationship.  I realize that director Rose Troche was trying to show us that a lesbian relationship is no different than a male and female relationship and even lesbians talk like men talk about women
column5: but somehow it just felt very dated and clich for me.  It didn't open more doors in my mind to the lifestyle of lesbians
column6: but instead gave me this dated image of this butch lesbian that is rebelling against something instead of embracing the true lifestyle.  The black and white photography
column7: while symbolically trying to show the black and white of the situation and relationship
column8: just felt like an art film.  This was an art film
column9: so what am I griping about?  I guess I just didn't want to see an art film with this topic.  I wanted to see something along the lines of Kids or even a documentary
column10: not something where the uneducated will laugh at and ridicule even harder.  I wanted a film that was going to punch me in the face
column11: not build upon dated/old clichs that instead poked my mind randomly and not very hard.  It was unimpressive.  It wasn't bold filmmaking
column12: but instead just this random
column13: average production about a lesbian love story.  Was it to be educational?  I think there were elements that could have been explored greater and into detail to cross that education/lifestyle acceptance line.  The scene dealing with bisexuality is the first that comes to mind.  This probably sounded great on paper
column14: but when it was actually filmed out
column15: it seemed high schoolish and bland.  The inner voices were not struggling with the character
column16: but instead causing confusion and chaos that will never be resolved.  Another scene that could have played out just a bit better was the dinner scene where a group of lesbians have gathered for a party.  There could have been more discussed between the lesbians like lifestyle
column17: issues
column18: and current problems (that would help with the dated feel) instead of just sex
column19: sex
column20: and more sex.  That was a huge downfall for me was the constant reminder that all these women wanted was to have sex.  There were times when I was watching this film where I felt a bit of sweetness in my mouth because I thought there was some candy-coating happening.  This does not need to happen in a film that is supposed to bring the lesbian lifestyle closer into the spotlight.  I never felt that these women in this film were given the best light to show their stuff anyway.  From the beginning of the first scene until the last (and all those snippets in-between) all they could talk about was sex.  They wanted to have sex more often than I honestly think about in a day.  It really made the rest of the non-existent themes seem blurry and unimportant.  There was just a consistent lack of togetherness for this film that ultimately hurt it in the long run.  This wasn't a film about women's rights
column21: but instead a dire attempt to show the similarities between homosexual and heterosexual relationships.  I agree that this happened
column22: but just not very coherently.  There seemed to be other elements strewn together in a very loose fashion that took away from the overall power of the film.  Don't get me wrong
column23: this could have been a very powerful film about a lifestyle that this world is still not accepting
column24: but instead it went too far to the left (which isn't bad
column25: except in this case) and chose to go the bleeding artist route instead of the informative
column26: here are the facts route.  The black and white photography
column27: the lack of character development (who really was Ely's partner?)
column28: and the cheesy moments between scenes where women talked to me about the illusive "honey pot".  It just wasn't coming together well for me and eventually fell apart all together.  Overall
column29: I was not impressed.  There are greater films out there that express the power of the relationship and do not create this unimpressive "raw" sensation by trying to shock the audiences.  One of my favorites is the film Big Eden which accepts homosexuality like it is commonplace in society.  If Go Fish would have been done in a similar style
column30: I think I could have walked away from the film with a better taste in my mouth.  Instead
column31: I am stuck with an unimpressive story that did nothing except joke about why lesbian women like to play the game "Go Fish".  Ha ha ha h....it just isn't working for me.  I do not recommend this film in the least bit.  There was one
column32: singular scene that made me chuckle and for the likes of me I cannot remember why.  It was an unmemorable feast of bad cinema.  Skip it.  Grade: * out of ****

This book shows the dichotomy that exists in modern-day America between the cutthroat environment that supposedly exists in the private sector
column2: and the easy-does-it culture fostered within the public sphere of schools
column3: government agencies
column4: etc...  The book makes the case that America's youth are basically coddled K-12
column5: and end up playing catch-up during and after college when working in the free-market culture of the private sector.    These conclusions have been elaborated on before in other publications
column6: and are only true to a certain degree.  For example
column7: the author gives examples of how Americans working in the private sector excel and achieve like citizens of no other country.  The author forgets to mention that nearly all the successful industries in this country
column8: especially those that have gone to spawn copycats in other countries
column9: were and are all supported and protected by government largess.  For example
column10: automobiles would only be rich men's toys today if it were not for all those roads and parking lots built by taxpayers.  Another example
column11: US agriculture would not have survived the Great Depression and become the world's leader in food produce if not for the introduction of farm subsidies
column12: government-funded agricultural research
column13: government-operated satellites and weather stations to monitor the weather
column14: and other government programs that directly or indirectly help farmers.  These and other established
column15: successful private industries would be nowhere without some "coddling" from US taxpayers.  Even if we dismiss the previous points
column16: I believe the author has only shown half the picture; specifically
column17: the author does not fully examine the question of why "coddling" occurs in schools and students are not prepared for the competition of the "real world".  The answer to this question connects the dichotomy so well illustrated by the author.  Specifically
column18: American adults are so busy surviving in the private sector that they have less time and effort to raise their kids to be good competitors themselves.  For example
column19: the character traits that makes for successful businesses: willingness of employees to relocate
column20: works long hours
column21: toeing the company line
column22: etc...
column23: are exactly the worse traits to follow when trying to raise kids well.   Raising kids well means living in stable communities with low turnover - this means minimal relocation of employees by businesses.   Raising kids well means spending time with them
column24: and not spending long hours at work.   Raising kids well means teaching them to stand up for what they believe in
column25: not what their peers (boss
column26: coworkers
column27: etc...) want them to do.    This then is what the author has totally missed out on in this book; an explanation of how the dichotomy between private sphere hard-nosed competetion
column28: and public sphere cushion jobs came about.  Because of this omission
column29: this book is merely commentary and observation
column30: and lacks insightful thought

column1: This is a messy book that succeeds (to the degree that it does so) despite its flaws.  Some of the subjects are covered well
column2: some covered poorly
column3: and even where there is coverage
column4: the discussions are maddeningly inconsistent.  First
column5: the good: author Otto Friedrich was energetic in finding many former residents of Berlin as sources for this work
column6: and some of the best parts of the book are their colorful reminiscences of their lost and ruined city.  Friedrich also included interesting chapters about the social milieu of the time
column7: particularly the cultural scene: classical music
column8: drama and the nascent motion picture industry.  And there are some nice character sketches of some of the leading artists of the era: Lotte Lenya
column9: Bertolt Brecht and various musicians.  In general
column10: despite the crazy-quilt nature of the coverage
column11: Friedrich is best on the social history aspects of Berlin.  Now
column12: the bad:  The book is very scattershot
column13: a mile wide
column14: but mostly an inch deep.  For example
column15: in the discussion of the German movie industry of the time
column16: although Marlene Dietrich and Emil Jannings are discussed
column17: Peter Lorre
column18: Ernst Lubistch and F.W. Murnau are discussed only in passing.  Among the pictorial artists
column19: George Grosz is covered and discussed
column20: but Becker
column21: Nolde and scores of other artists get superficial or non-existent coverage.  And maybe it is inevitable to try to discuss the tangled political history of the Weimar era and the rise of the Nazis in a history of Berlin
column22: but Friedrich is not a professional historian
column23: and his weaknesses in this area are glaring.  Any reader with even a passing interest in the Weimar era will find far better accounts of the politics of the period than Friedrich's book. And even if you grant that he needed to discuss the political events of the day in  his work
column24: there's a lamentable lack of focus to his political coverage
column25: which mirrors the overall unevenness of this work.  For example
column26: his descriptions of the combat in the streets between the Freikorps and the Communists in the immediate post-war period have the freshness and vitality that come from the testimony of eyewitnesses
column27: and they give the reader a sense for the chaos that became horrifyingly prevalent in Berlin.  But his discussion of Germany's policies toward the payment of reparations (the Dawes plan and the Young plan
column28: etc.) is
column29: at best
column30: superficial and misleading.  If you read this book
column31: you might consider reading the sections that deal with the social history of the period and just skipping (or finding better sources for) the political history.

Sebastian Mallaby certainly can tell a story and is an excellent writer.  Unfortunately
column2: in his latest book on the World Bank and its President
column3: his sharp and witty pen is often aimed squarely at the wrong target.    In order to maintain his narrative thread
column4: Mallaby resorts to broadside attacks on any non-governmental organization that has the gall to critique Bank projects and policies
column5: and insist that the Bank adhere to minimum social and environmental safeguards when dealing with the overwhelmingly corrupt
column6: authoritarian regimes that comprise its borrowers.  It is disturbing that he would choose to "shoot the messenger" (i.e. the NGOs) rather than take an honest look at their valid concerns. In this way
column7: Mallaby does both the Bank and his readers a disservice.  Despite the heavily footnoted text
column8: he ignores inconvenient facts and information that is readily available
column9: and uses clever put-downs and caricatures to demean the NGO community when he cannot respond to their genuine concerns with a viable argument.  His examination of a Chinese government-sponsored population transfer project in an historically Tibetan area is a particularly egregious example of the excesses and intellectual dishonesty of Mallaby's book.  It is most unfortunate that such a gifted writer approached such an important topic with such an incredible bias.  Too bad that Mr. Mallaby did not put his cleverness to better use

column1: OK. If you're going to create a pictorial accompaniment to a controversial movie
column2: AT LEAST PUT IN THE BEST PICTURES!!!  "The Passion of the Christ" intersperses stills from the movie with snippets from the passion section of the gospels. But whatever its value as a devotional or meditative aid
column3: it is missing nearly all of the over-the-top images from the movie. There's no snake in Gethsemane; no clear image of Satan; no Jesus hanging off the bridge; no demon children hounding Judas; none of the nastiest scourging scenes; no long stairway to ascend with the cross; no shroud image on Veronica's cloth; no flipping Jesus on his face; no shoulder dislocation; no eye-piercing crow.   Virtually none of the images that stayed with me from the movie are included. I wonder why not? Were these scenes too gruesome when transferred to the printed page? Or were they rendered silly when they could be studied at leisure? I can't figure out Mel Gibson for adding these gruesome scenes to the film. I understand less why he left them out of the book. Weird

column1: What does it mean when a writer of this caliber admits--in interviews and in public
column2: to friends--that he is publishing a book that isn't his best effort?  Lethem is a somewhat talented writer
column3: but he betrays his audience by publishing a half-baked book that serves only as a stop -gap
column4: and then offers it to the film world as a gift.  A gift--Lewis Hyde would agree--is meant to be given in good faith.  You wouldn't hand someone a half-baked cake as a gift. But he gets to have his cake and eat it too by assuming the position that this novel is worth handing over as a gift.  It was light
column5: not finished
column6: and too easy for a writer of his skill.  As Kundera states in his new book: "Artist fame is the most monstrous of all
column7: for it implies the idea of immortality.  And that is a diabolical snare
column8: because the grotesquely megalomanic ambition to survive one's death is inseparably bound to the artist's probity.  Every novel created with real passion aspires quite naturally to a lasting aesthetic value
column9: meaning to a value capable of surving its author. To write without having that ambition is cynicism: a mediocre plumber may be useful to people
column10: but a mediocre novelist who consciously produces books that are ephemeral
column11: commonplace
column12: conventional--thus not useful
column13: thus burdensome
column14: thus noxious--is contemptible."  I don't think Lethem is exactly contemptible. But he is selling out to the idea of fame itself.

column6: regardless of who (Cam's wife Allie) got hurt.  Allie was described early on in the book as someone who people walk all over.  I never got that impression.  She was the owner of her own business
column7: and she was determined to help Cam's cousin Jamie.  She also happened to be a woman deeply in love with her husband.  It was her love and loyalty that Cam felt totally comfortable in betraying.  At one point late in the book
column8: Allie asks Cam if he and Mia had laughed at her.  He tells her no.  However in a way
column9: they did
column10: considering they had no problem having sex in her flower shop and her bed.  I felt for Allie. Instead it was more about infidelity and how far a person is willing to go for someone they love.  Infidelity seems to be a pretty constant story line in most of Picoult's books (I understand her latest book
column11: THE TENTH CIRCLE is no different.)  She is without a doubt an excellent writer

column1: I read Armies of the Night for a graduate school class.  I found this novel/history very difficult to read.  I would sometimes find myself reading a page over three times before I could get anything out of it.  It was inaccessible
column2: frustrating
column3: and in short order I felt great hostility bordering on hatred for the author.  For example
column4: early in the book Mailer announces to a room full of people that he had just urinated all over the restroom floor when he could find neither the light switch nor the urinal.  He is inebriated at the time.  Perhaps he intended this to be a humorous revelation
column5: I thought it was obnoxious.  Another example of Mailer's ego
column6: is when he states early in the book that he is "probably willing to die" for the anti-war cause.  This is revealed as macho swagger because at the moment of truth
column7: Mailer is unwilling to even do a paltry five days in jail for the cause.  He complains about the conditions in jail; he can't shave and his clothes get dirty.  I thought the authorities were generous to provide everyone a bed to sleep in
column8: as well as meals
column9: coffee
column10: and reading material but this was apparently insufficient for Mr. Mailer as he finds fault with all of it.    The book gets better when we leave Mailer's personal experience and are finally permitted to learn something about the brave young men and women who made up the heart of the protest.  Some of the protesters spent the night in the cold outside the Pentagon
column11: some were beaten by the guards
column12: and others had water poured on them while they were sleeping.  Unfortunately this part of the book is much briefer than Mailer's narrative.  For me
column13: this book is ruined by Mailer's self-important posturing.  If the author's goal was to make readers hate him
column14: I think he succeeded.  I have utterly no idea why this book won a Pulitzer Prize.  Perhaps it is an example of the adage "you had to be there."  I have read Mailer's other Pulitzer Prize winner
column15: The Executioner's Song
column16: and I liked it.   This book however
column17: was awful.

column4: the subject of the James boys is inherently fascinating and
column5: yes
column6: Ted Yeatman's research was extensive
column7: which is worth one extra star
column8: but as a writer he failed to present his material in an interesting fashion.  First
column9: he is too much in love with facts and uses them whether they are necessary or not.  (I do not need to know
column10: as just one example
column11: the name of every insignificant Missouri militia outfit that ever marched in the same county as the James boys unless that name is relevant to them.  Footnotes would have been a better location if Yeatman felt compelled to include this arcane data.)  Another reason the narrative bogs down is that Yeatman failed to heed his word processor's grammar checker when it pointed out the thousands of passive sentences he wrote.  Or perhaps he had that feature turned off.  If so
column12: he should flick it back on immediately.  Lastly
column13: a good writer spins out a narrative that flows like water.  Yeatman's jumbled writing contains too many icebergs the reader must dodge or sink in the process.  I am not yet finished reading it and am not certain that I can continue to the end much as I want to learn about the James boys.  What a shame.  Bad writing made this book a great waste of the author's extensive knowledge.  I fail to understand why Cumberland House published this book without extensive editing or not publish it at all.  Obviously

column1: Dembski's very first sentence says his goal is to write so that he cannot be misunderstood.  He fails badly
column2: even on key issues.  Consider:  Dembski insists ID is legitimate science and emphatically denies that ID is religiously motivated.  Well
column3: let's look at the evidence.    Curiously enough
column4: most of the essays and virtually all of the authors have a much stronger connection to religion than to science.    On the religion side of the ledger
column5: co-editor Kushiner is the editor of a religious magazine.  Dembski himself teaches at a seminary and says that if there's a designer behind biology
column6: the designer is probably God. Nancy Pearcey's degree from a theological seminary is not in science
column7: and her essay
column8: like several others
column9: included heavy doses of Christian moralizing.  Jay Wesley Richards' degree is in theology
column10: and he says ID is a valuable resource for Christian apologetics.  John West
column11: Jr.
column12: writes and edits religious publications.  Patrick Henry Reardon is a pastor and edits a Christian magazine.  John Mark Reynolds teaches philosophy at a Bible Institute and supports his arguments with quotes from the Bible.  Part of his essay is titled "Intelligent Design Lets God In."  Behe supplements his arguments about irreducible complexity with quotes from the Pope.  Stephen Meyer teaches philosophy at a fundamentalist college.  Jonathan Wells' own website openly proclaims his religious motivation.  Paul Nelson is a philosopher
column13: not a scientist (though his essay on the "tautology problem
column14: though not really relevant to the scientific validity of evolutionary biology, was actually pretty interesting).  John Wiester teaches at a Bible Institute and is a prominent member of an evangelical organization.  Walter Bradley's essay contained this quote:  We know that nature is described by the best of all possible mathematics because God created it."    The science side
column15: in contrast
column16: is very thin.  Phillip Johnson's last formal science class was in high school
column17: over 40 years ago.  Only a mid-life
column18: religious crisis prompted his interest in ID.  Michael Behe's contribution on irreducible complexity (IC) seems scientific enough.  Too bad both he and Dembski admitted the year after the essay was published that Behe's formulation was seriously flawed.  (Which makes the several other contributors' statements about the "massive evidence" for IC look that much dumber.)  (For more info on Behe's Blunder
column19: see my review of "Darwin's Black Box.")  Wells' chapter mentions scientific issues
column20: but his arguments for ID are based exclusively on analogies and negative arguments
column21: neither of which constitutes affirmative evidence for ID.  DeHaan is a psychologist and Wiester has only a bachelor's degree
column22: and that's in geology.  Putting their essay on the Cambrian Explosion on the "science" side of the ledger is a pure gift
column23: since much of what they said was just unbelievable gibberish.  (Species should precede phyla???  There should be intermediates between living species???  New phyla should constantly be emerging???  These people are ID-iots!)  Plus
column24: all their arguments were negative arguments against evolution
column25: and
column26: obviously
column27: such arguments do nothing to support ID.  Putting Bradley's essay on the "science" side of the ledger is also a gift
column28: since it amounted to nothing more than pure speculation about cosmology
column29: an area in which Bradley
column30: a materials scientist and engineer
column31: listed no qualifications.  Listing Dembski's essay as science is also a gift
column32: since it dealt with information theory
column33: an area in which Dembski lists no qualifications.  Also
column34: most of his arguments were mere analogies
column35: and analogies are not evidence.  Also
column36: he relied very heavily on Behe's IC.  In fact
column37: since Dembski also proclaimed that "ID readily embraces the sacramental nature of physical reality.  Indeed
column38: ID is just the Logos theology of John's Gospel restated in the idiom of information theory" (191) I think Dembski's essay should be re-assigned to the religion side.  Bruce Gordon
column39: a philosopher of physics
column40: displays his cluelessness about biology by gushing over IC.  Gordon's cluelessness is also reflected in his assertion that the McLean court's definition of "science" was a "put-up job" by evos.  If Gordon had bothered to read the trial transcript
column41: he would have found that the creationists completely agreed with that definition.  In fact
column42: as the May 2005 curriculum hearings in Kansas showed
column43: most ID-iots still use the McLean definition!  How can that possibly be evos' fault???  Weighing the relative amounts of religion and science
column44: religion obviously predominates by a very wide margin.  No wonder so many of the favorable reviews focused on religious issues.  So again
column45: if Dembski's goal was to demonstrate ID's scientific nature
column46: he failed miserably.    Also interesting was Dembski's claim that he was "startled" about how evos misunderstand ID as implying skill in design
column47: or even perfection.  According to Dembski
column48: "intelligence" actually means "nothing more than being the result of an intelligent agent
column49: even one who acts stupidly."  Hmmm.  God isn't dead after all
column50: just stupid.  That's reassuring.    In any case
column51: there's no justification for blaming evos for misunderstanding ID's position on perfection
column52: since the misinformation comes from ID's own textbooks.  The most widely used textbook is "Of Pandas and People" (see my review of "Pandas")
column53: currently the focus of litigation in Dover
column54: PA.  Pandas' authors take great pains to document the exquisite skill
column55: i.e.
column56: perfection
column57: of their examples of biological design.    Since the people who contributed to Pandas did such a horribly botched job -- Intelligence implies skill?  Ridiculous!  --  maybe Dembski would prefer that we simply ignore those poor
column58: misguided fools.  Sound reasonable?  Well
column59: the contributors to Pandas include such misguided fools as Nancy Pearcey
column60: Michael Behe
column63: and Walter Bradley!    Dembski also rails about how dogmatic evos are
column64: and he stresses how necessary it is for scientists to remain tentative about their theories.  But Meyer teaches at a school that requires its faculty to swear an oath to maintain Christian beliefs.  Is that an example of being tentative?  And Dembski himself recently demonstrated his own open-mindedness by proclaiming that he would never abandon his faith in ID
column65: regardless of the evidence.    And that's why we call them ID-iots.

The science behind evolution is not easy to grasp

column7: let alone a two million year old fossil
column8: if it meant keeping his belief system intact. That is the only conclusion I can draw from reading these books. Its arguments are clever

This piece of garbage will never convince anyone who actually knows what evolution is that ID is a superior hypothesis for the origination of all life on earth. To be as blunt as possible

column13: but practically every study that's ever been done on the issue of religiosity and intelligence supports that claim.   There can be no denying that certain types of people simply don't accept the claims of creationism and ID or become bible thumpers. These include people the likes of Albert Einstein

The types of people that uncritically and blindly accept the creation myth of Genesis despite its obvious conflict with reality are typically found in... well the bible belt states of the good ol' US of A. They may also be found dancing with snakes
column18: relating their latest alien abduction stories to friends
column19: riding around with shotguns in pick ups while hatching new conspiracy theories about the dishonest motives behind science's desire to hide the evidence for bigfoot.   Seriously though folks
column20: is it more logical to be a Christian? Is religion the natural choice of a smart person familiar with more of the evidence? Not according to a broad consensus of studies on IQ and religiosity. These studies have consistently found that the lower the IQ score
column21: the more likely a person is to be religious. To place these studies in perspective
column22: it is helpful to know the general religious attitudes of Americans today. According to a February 1995 Gallup poll
column23: 96 percent of all Americans believe in God
column24: and 88 percent affirm the importance of religion. However
column25: the degree of religiosity within this group varies considerably. Only 35 percent can be classified as "religious
column26: using a definition that requires them to consider religion important and attend religious services at least once a week. And a March 1994 Gallup poll found that only 20 percent of all Americans belong to that politically active group known as Christian conservatives."   The following is a review of several studies of IQ and religiosity
column27: paraphrased and summarized from Burnham Beckwith's article
column28: "The Effect of Intelligence on Religious Faith
column29: Free Inquiry, Spring 1986: (1)   STUDIES OF STUDENTS   1. Thomas Howells, 1927  Study of 461 students showed religiously conservative students are
column30: in general
column31: relatively inferior in intellectual ability."   2. Hilding Carlsojn
column32: 1933  Study of 215 students showed that "there is a tendency for the more intelligent undergraduate to be sympathetic toward... atheism."   3. Abraham Franzblau
column33: 1934  Confirming Howells and Carlson
column34: tested 354 Jewish children
column35: aged 10-16. Found a negative correlation between religiosity and IQ as measured by the Terman intelligence test.   4. Thomas Symington
column36: 1935  Tested 400 young people in colleges and church groups. He reported
column37: "There is a constant positive relation in all the groups between liberal religious thinking and mental ability... There is also a constant positive relation between liberal scores and intelligence..."   5. Vernon Jones
column38: 1938  Tested 381 students
column39: concluding "a slight tendency for intelligence and liberal attitudes to go together."   6. A. R. Gilliland
column40: 1940  At variance with all other studies
column41: found "little or no relationship between intelligence and attitude toward god."   7. Donald Gragg
column42: 1942  Reported an inverse correlation between 100 ACT freshman test scores and Thurstone "reality of god" scores.   8. Brown and Love
column43: 1951  At the University of Denver
column44: tested 613 male and female students. The mean test scores of non-believers was 119 points
column45: and for believers it was 100. The non-believers ranked in the 80th percentile
column46: and believers in the 50th. Their findings "strongly corroborate those of Howells."   9. Michael Argyle
column47: 1958  Concluded that "although intelligent children grasp religious concepts earlier
column48: they are also the first to doubt the truth of religion
column49: and intelligent students are much less likely to accept orthodox beliefs."   10. Jeffrey Hadden
column50: 1963  Found no correlation between intelligence and grades. This was an anomalous finding
column51: since GPA corresponds closely with intelligence. Other factors may have influenced the results at the University of Wisconsin.   11. Young
column52: Dustin and Holtzman
column53: 1966  Average religiosity decreased as GPA rose.   12. James Trent
column54: 1967  Polled 1400 college seniors. Found little difference
column55: but high-ability students in his sample group were over-represented.   13. C. Plant and E. Minium
column56: 1967  The more intelligent students were less religious
column57: both before entering college and after 2 years of college.   14. Robert Wuthnow
column58: 1978  Of 532 students
column59: 37 percent of Christians
column60: 58 percent of apostates
column61: and 53 percent of non-religious scored above average on SATs.   15. Hastings and Hoge
column63: 1974  Polled 200 college students and found no significant correlations between religiosity and intelligence.   16. Norman Poythress
column64: 1975  Mean SATs for strongly anti-  religious (1148)
column68: 1980  Studied 158 male and female Canadian university students. They reported "nonreligious S's tended to be strongly intelligent" and "more intelligent than religious S's."   STUDENT BODY COMPARISONS   1. Rose Goldsen
column69: 1952  Percentage of students who believe in a divine god: Harvard 30; UCLA 32; Dartmouth 35; Yale 36; Cornell 42; Wayne 43; Weslyan 43; Michigan 45; Fisk 60; Texas 62; North Carolina 68.   2. National Review Study
column70: 1970  Percentage of students who believe in a Spirit or Divine God: Reed 15; Brandeis 25; Sarah Lawrence 28; Williams 36; Stanford 41; Boston U. 41; Yale 42; Howard 47; Indiana 57; Davidson 59; S. Carolina 65; Marquette 77.   3. Caplovitz and Sherrow
column71: 1977  Apostasy rates rose continuously from 5 percent in "low" ranked schools to 17 percent in "high" ranked schools.   4. Niemi
column75: organized religion was judged important by only 26 percent of their students
column76: compared with 44 percent of all students.   STUDIES OF VERY-HIGH IQ GROUPS   1. Terman
column77: 1959  Studied group with IQ's over 140. Of men
column79: of women 18 percent. Sixty-two percent of men and 57 percent of women claimed "little religious inclination" while 28 percent of the men and 23 percent of the women claimed it was "not at all important."   2. Warren and Heist
column80: 1960  Found no differences among National Merit Scholars. Results may have been effected by the fact that NM scholars are not selected on the basis of intelligence or grades alone
column81: but also on "leadership" and such like.   3. Southern and Plant
column82: 1968  Studied 42 male and 30 female members of Mensa. Mensa members were much less religious in belief than the typical American college alumnus or adult.   STUDIES Of SCIENTISTS   1. William S. Ament
column84: president of the University of Michigan
column85: checked persons listed in Who's Who in America: "Unitarians
column89: and Presbyterians [who are less religious] are... far more numerous in Who's Who than would be expected on the basis of the population which they form. Baptists
column91: and Catholics are distinctly less numerous."   Ament confirmed Little's conclusion. He noted that Unitarians
column93: were more than 40 times as numerous in Who's Who as in the U.S. population.   2. Lehman and Witty
column94: 1931  Identified 1189 scientists found in both Who's Who (1927) and American Men of Science (1927). Only 25 percent of those listed in the latter and 50 percent of those in the former reported their religious denomination
column95: despite the specific request to do so
column96: under the heading of "religious denomination (if any)." Well over 90 percent of the general population claims religious affiliation. The figure of 25 percent suggests far less religiosity among scientists.   Unitarians were 81.4 times as numerous among eminent scientists as non-Unitarians.   3. Kelley and Fisk
column97: 1951  Found a negative (-.39) correlation between the strength of religious values and research competence. [How these were measured is unknown.]   4. Ann Roe
column99: nearly all members of the prestigious National Academy of Sciences or the American Philosophical Society. She reported that
column100: while nearly all of them had religious parents and had attended Sunday school
column101: 'now only three of these men are seriously active in church. A few others attend upon occasion
column102: or even give some financial support to a church which they do not attend... All the others have long since dismissed religion as any guide to them
column103: and the church plays no part in their lives... A few are militantly atheistic
column104: but most are just not interested.'"   5. Francis Bello
column105: 1954  Interviewed or questionnaired 107 nonindustrial scientists under the age of 40 judged by senior colleagues to be outstanding. Of the 87 responses
column106: 45 percent claimed to be "agnostic or atheistic" and an additional 22 percent claimed no religious affiliation. For 20 most eminent
column107: "the proportion who are now a-religious is considerably higher than in the entire survey group."   6. Jack Chambers
column108: 1964  Questionnaired 740 US psychologists and chemists. He reported
column109: "The highly creative men... significantly more often show either no preference for a particular religion or little or no interest in religion." Found that the most eminent psychologists showed 40 percent no preference
column110: 16 percent for the most eminent chemists.   7. Vaughan
column116: and geologists listed in American Men of Science (1955) on church membership
column118: and belief in afterlife. Of the 642 replies
column119: 38.5 percent did not believe in an afterlife
column120: whereas 31.8 percent did. Belief in immortality was less common among major university staff than among those employed by business
column122: or minor universities. The Gallup poll taken about this time showed that two-thirds of the U.S. population believed in an afterlife
column123: so scientists were far less religious than the typical adult.   Conclusion   The consensus here is clear: more intelligent people tend not to believe in religion. And this observation is given added force when you consider that the above studies span a broad range of time
column125: and yet arrive at the same conclusion.   This is the result even when the researchers are Christian conservatives themselves. One such researcher is George Gallup.   Why does this correlation exist? The first answer that comes to mind is that religious beliefs tend to be more illogical or incoherent than secular beliefs
column126: and intelligent people tend to recognize that more quickly. But this explanation will surely be rejected by religious people
column127: who will seek other explanations and rationalizations.   A possible counter-argument is that intelligent people tend to be more successful than others. The lure of worldly success and materialism draws many of these intellectually gifted individuals away from God. After all
column128: who needs God when you (apparently) are making it on your own?   However
column129: this argument does not withstand closer scrutiny. Most of the studies outlined above describe the religious attitudes of students
column130: who have yet to enter the working world
column131: much less succeed in it. Some might then argue that the most intelligent students are nonetheless succeeding in school. But "success" in school (for those who may have forgotten!) is more measured in terms of popularity
column136: etc. Grades are but one of many measures of success in a young person's life -- one that is increasingly becoming less important
column137: as many social critics point out.   The simplest and most parsimonious explanation is that religion is a set of logical and factual claims
column138: and those with the most logic and facts at their disposal are rejecting it largely on those grounds

column1: The author knows his stuff. And if I had NOT been familiar with spiritual writings (or self-help books) I might have gotten seduced by the 'logic' of the arguments or the promises for improving my relationships.   However.  To me
column2: the emphasis of the presentation on the workings of the mind and spirit makes only more obvious its dissociation from the body and emotions. This book will help most people with their relationships the way yoga helps people to be flexible - through dissociation. In both cases a methodical disconnection from  the emotional markers held in the body creates a temporary sense of freedom and relief. But
column3: these very markers hold in place personal history and uniqueness of one's life experience - not to mention energy trapped in suppressed emotions.   To say that I found this book pretty useless for me
column4: is unfortunately not enough - I believe this book is dangerous in what it creates through its seductions - a sort of spiritual and emotional brain washing. Sure
column5: it contains powerful techniques for change - so does brain washing. And. Dissociation works quite well at first - that's why people dissociate - because it works. But. Is this a choice I really want to make? No.  I don't doubt that Mr. Grayson has found a way to make the techniques in his book work for him. I also don't doubt that they worked for his clients - over time therapists polarize the clients they draw by the very nature of the approaches they refine. But. That doesn't make such an approach a good thing. The perspective which this book represents is not one I would choose for my own relationships - it would be insulting and hurtful to the people I love. I want to be close to the people I love
column6: not float on a cloud of abstractions
column7: basking in self-satisfied detachment. Neither would I want to attract into close relationships the kind of people this book would attract.  I'm 47 years old
column8: married for 13 years
column9: with two children. I am an illustrator-artist (27 years)
column10: organic grower (11years) and a licensed bodyworker (14 years). I've read spiritual writings and self-help books since I was 15
column11: and until about 5 years ago. This book was recommended to me by a well-meaning
column12: casual friend

column1: Upon its initial release
column2: the attention that Otto Preminger's "Anatomy of a Murder" attracted due to its subject matter undoubtedly deflected some attention away from the fact that the film had its fair share of problems.  When watched today after much of its scandalous elements have lost their power to shock
column3: its meandering story and uneven characterizations are exposed front and center.    Attorney Paul Biegler (James Stewart) is asked to defend Lieutenant Frederick Manion (Ben Gazzara) after a bar owner is found murdered.  Manion claims that he committed the murder in a fit of rage after his wife
column4: Laura (Lee Remick)
column5: was raped.  While preparing his case for trial
column6: Biegler finds that Laura is extremely difficult to work with because of her temperamental and flirtatious nature.  Nevertheless
column7: the resourceful attorney continues to work on exonerating his client even though it is not clear whether he and his wife are being entirely truthful with him.   Stewart is his dependable self in "Anatomy of a Murder."  In fact
column8: his performance as an attorney who is not afraid to stretch the rules is the one saving grace of the film.  There is little nuance in the performances of Gazzara and Remick and even the great George C. Scott misses the mark with an over-the-top effort.  Yet
column9: the problems with the acting is secondary to the unfocused screenplay.  "Anatomy of a Murder" oftentimes seems more concerned with exploring the eccentric natures of its characters than in telling a good story.  The investigation of the crime is done in a half-hearted manner and the mystery behind the dual crimes of the rape and the murder are never resolved to any satisfaction.  For a film to run as long as "Anatomy of a Murder" does
column10: one would think that there would be more than enough time to resolve all of the lingering questions posed by the film.  Yet
column11: this is not the case

column1: I really had a problem with this book.  This is my first encounter with Feist's work
column2: and I'm finding it difficult to give him a second chance.  From reading other reviews
column3: it seems that people who have read previous works by Feist derive some enjoyment from the world this book is written in
column4: as well as the presence of some familiar characters.  Since I lacked this prior knowledge about Midkemia and its inhabitants
column5: I was left to judge the book purely for the quality of the fiction
column6: and I found it to be uninspiring.    Talon is an incredibly shallow character.  His thoughts and actions are polarized and always single faceted.  If at any time during a book you can describe the complete emotional state of the main character in one word
column7: the author is probably doing something wrong.  While this is bad
column8: it is not disastrous; except when you consider that Feist conveys Talon's emotions to us in a totally uninteresting way.  I believe the addage is
column9: "show
column10: don't tell."  It didn't seem like any of Talon's emotions were real because they were conveyed in such a mind-numbing manner.  It seemed to me that Talon was forced along by the plot rather than guided by his emotions.  Furthermore
column11: Talon's transformation from mountain boy to noble swordsman extraordinaire was unbelievable to the point of being ridiculous.  How Feist can expect us to swallow this garbage while he skips over years of Talon's training and culturing is truly remarkable.  I do not have a problem with Feist's plot idea of turning a country bumpkin into a hero (it is a hallmark fantasy plot)
column12: but you have to make the reader believe it.  A few chapters of magic school
column13: snippets of verbal training
column14: and a few sword bouts are not enough to raise this character to the level that Feist has raised him.    Other characters in this book were similarly shallow.  I really saw no difference between any of Talon's trainers except their professions.  You could literally exchange the dialogue between Caleb and Robert
column15: or Caleb and Magnus
column16: or any other similar pair
column17: and you would not notice the difference.  They all spoke exactly the same way
column18: and taught similar lessons.  The battle sequences were dull
column19: ambiguous
column20: and failed to excite me.  The language Feist used was simple and boring more often than not.  Do yourself a favor and read George R.R. Martin's or Terry Goodkind's series instead of this one.

column1: It is bad enough that this is a poor book with no balance
column2: but to require it as a text in post-graduate studies in education almost brings on apoplexy.  It is a secular humanist apoligia for multiculturalism in education.  It is singular in point of view
column3: never straying from the thesis that multiculturalism is good and schools must support it; hardly the sort of reference work for a university level discussion of the issues.  The philosophy behind the book is that people are hardly more or less than those cultural elements which have been socialized into them with little responsibility for their beliefs or actions.  The main text is that every culture is equally valuable in society
column4: forgetting that "society" is essentially American culture with its own priorities.  They go into great detail on the virtues of immigrant cultures and the vices of the American culture
column5: hardly accepting that it has a right to exist as well.  The most difficult aspect of this is the authors' almost laughable inability to get outside of their point of view and treat the issues with something approaching objectivity.  The book is unbearable in its "holier than thou" attitude.  I don't know if this is typical of the ilk but if so
column6: it is hardly a wonder that the multicultural mavens have difficulty selling their point of vie

column9: although the lessons of what abuse is

column11: and how difficult it can be to escape are good ones to learn about
column12: even in a fictional context.  Anna Quindlen is also the author of One True Thing
column13: a book-cum-film about a daughter's experience with her mother's terminal cancer. That book is good--realistic
column14: emotional but not maudlin
column15: and challenging. Black and Blue is merely an example of weak writing that reads like a made-for-TV movie. It made its way into Oprah's book club but would never make it on to  my must-read lists. Facing the realities of abuse is a good lesson to learn
column16: and so the subject is worth reading about
column17: but Quindlen's portrayal is less than realistic or compelling. All of the checklist facts are there: abuse leads to abuse
column18: specifically carried from father to son; some women are drawn to the type of men that are/become abusers; legal protection can be inadequate; violence can lead to death. So on
column19: so forth. The list of facts is there but the emotional context is filmsy
column20: centers on children (rather than personal strength) and strange
column21: powerless situations. Even when she flees her husband
column22: things seem to be done to the protagonist rather than done by her. It's unfulfilling and disappointing to the reader and detracts from the whole text. In fact
column23: the more interesting characters are mere foils and supporting roles like her new friends and romantic interest. They seem to have more personality and depth than the protagonist.  It will take less time and energy
column24: and induce the same emotional responce
column25: to watch any one of the numerous women's TV daytime movies about the same subject. Black and Blue is gripping only because you want to know if her husband will find her or not
column26: and presents very few challenges
column27: either in the writing or the ideas
column28: to the reader. It's readable and I was able to get through it
column29: but it's still a poor example of literature and even of the lesson it attempts to teach. Don't waste your time on this one

As a US citizen
column2: I am both embarrassed and angry.  I am embarrassed that anyone in the Federal government
column3: and particularly anyone with ties to the military
column4: would treat remote viewing with any credibility whatsoever.  I am also angry that my tax dollars have been used to support programs of this type.  One does not have to be a "hard core skeptic" to understand that McConeagle has found a niche for himself deluding others about his so-called abilities.  The basic difference between McConeagle and other charlatans is that (1) my tax money helped pay for his activities
column5: and (2) his "work" may have influenced some important decisions.  No "psychic" or "remote viewer" has ever provided signficiant assistance in any criminal investigation.  They simply stand back and make general assertions about the "accuracy" of their work after the fact.  The same is true of MConeagle
column6: who fails to offer shred of credible evidence that he has ever successfully performed remote viewing.  He has hand-picked some events for which he can at least claim that there was some similarity between his "viewing" and the actual circumstances.  It's amazing how a rough sketch can not only fit the profile of the superstructure of a sinking ship
column7: but can also be interpreted as the collapsed walls of a multi-story building destroyed by a car bomb.  As a matter of fact
column8: I think it looks quite a bit like the unfinished Death Star from "Star Wars"
column9: too.  I'm giving this book one star instead of zero stars simply because I think that it's important for citizens to read this book and then take political action to ensure that programs like this are never funded again

column1: Like Kenneth Haugks book
column2: Antagonists in the Church
column3: G. Lloyd Rediger promotes an approach to church conflict which will invariably result in individuals being unfairly labeled as clergy killers or antagonists which then is used to justify limiting their involvement in church communities. Dr. Rediger defines levels of conflict based on the histories of those involved. He therefore labels as abnormal any conflict when one or more of the persons involved have a psychiatric history especially a history of being abused. This is not a useful or valid approach. If you follow his reasoning to its logical conclusion
column4: he is advocating that 25% of women (the estimated rate of sexual abuse in this country) be excluded from church leadership positions because they were victimized as children. His line of reasoning results in his labeling a business tycoons abuse of power as normal conflict since there is no known history of prior emotional disturbance. He also advocates that any lay person making a complaint against a minister be investigated to determine their psychiatric history. The ethics of his approach are never considered. Rather than label conflict as normal or abnormal based on individual personal histories
column5: a fairer and more ethical approach would be to examine specific behaviors and find effective ways to promote positive outcomes for the majority of individuals involved. It is possible to reach consensus even when individuals are being difficult. Despite these serious limitations
column6: Dr. Rediger does promote a healthier lifestyle for pastors and advocates that an effective grievance process be in place in all church communities

column14: really like her and fear for her safety.  I don't know how or where Dean Koontz learned about bioethics
column15: but he has a terribly misguided view of the field
column16: taking an extreme sect of it to represent the main viewpoint of the field.  Further
column17: he states multiple times that these eugenic bioethics principles are being taught to medical students at major universities (who will have to pay for their involvement with evil bioethics) -- as a medical student
column18: I can assure you that this is patently untrue.  That Koontz could be so off-base on a topic that directly relates to the central motive is disconcerting and makes an already weak book even harder to swallow.  The final issue is Koontz's near-deification of dogs
column19: particularly Golden Retrievers
column20: which is a common motif in his more recent works.  It is ridiculous and unintentionally funny to an almost painful degree.  His obsession with dogs and their mystical powers borders on the psychotic (and I like dogs).  This novel probably features the most egregious example of Koontz's tendency to create overly sappy
column21: sugary-sweet endings.  Dean Koontz has written many books better than this one.  Spend your money on one of his stronger efforts

column1: "Crank" is a disgusting and despicable piece of nihilistic porn for people with sick minds and sick souls. Like most Americans of my generation
column2: TV and movies have inured me to images of violence and depravity
column3: but "Crank" (and similar movies like "The Punisher") managed to overcome that insensitivity and simply nauseated me. It's not necessarily the subject matter; many other movies have just as much violence
column4: sex
column5: drug use
column6: etc. without being so offensive. The difference is that those movies use the depiction of evil to develop a plot or character and that the demarcation line between good and evil is usually clearly understood. "Macbeth" is full of murder
column7: but we know that he is an evil character and we see him get his comeuppance. Dirty Harry blasts bad guys but we know that he is doing so in pursuit of law and justice. William Wallace may slice off enemies' heads in battle but we see that he is fighting for freedom against tyranny. The difference with "Crank" is that this movie has no moral compass whatsoever. Its protagonist is just as evil and depraved as the people he's fighting. It throws violence and perversion in our faces ad nauseam solely to titillate the reptilian mind with violence and perversion
column8: which is why I call it porn. Its ethic is nihilism and its view of humanity is purely animalistic. I give it 2 stars simply for its technical slickness. It was well-made but what self-respecting
column9: healthy human being could possibly watch this movie and not feel dirty afterwards

column1: Until reading this book
column2: I loved just about everything written by Mr Clancy
column3: although I've mostly read his older books. He has always been known for complex
column4: realistic plots and impressive descriptions of military hardware and modern warfare.  He forgot to include any of that in this book
column5: however. While the premise (a war between China and Russia) is very interesting
column6: "The Bear and the Dragon" doesn't deliver.  The first problem is that it takes an extremely long time to get going. The actual attack doesn't start until 900 pages into the book
column7: and there's really no justification for that much buildup. It doesn't really help that much of those 900 pages consist of Clancy giving his opinion about just about everything from communism
column8: to abortion
column9: to tax rates. While he does make a couple of good points (mind you
column10: just a couple)
column11: for the most part it's irrelevant and awfully short-sighted: Mr Clancy spends an awful lot of time telling us just how stupid and barbaric the Chinese (leaders) are
column12: while shamelessly glorifying the American Way (read
column13: "Republican Way") at every turn. It's almost disturbing to see how much the writer is convinced of the moral superiority of his convictions.  The part of the 900 pages that aren't filled with political tirade fare a bit better
column14: but there's still a lot of filler and repetition in them
column15: including a murder investigation that ultimately adds next to nothing to the real story. Which is a shame
column16: because there really is a fairly decent story (once you get over the fact that in this book
column17: the bad guys are incredibly stupid) hidden somewhere in all these pages.  Anyway
column18: I kept reading this "bear" of a book
column19: hoping that it would get better once the action started. It really didn't. The Chines attack
column20: and overrun the Russian defenses
column21: but after that they're so utterly and totally slaughtered by the USA that it's hard to take seriously: American and Russian jets kill Chinese planes by the dozens while suffering marginal casualties themselves
column22: hundreds of tanks are taken out in mere minutes
column23: and the Chinese field commander conveniently and inexplicably gets himself shot by a sniper. Right.   "The Bear and the Dragon" is 900 pages of communist/China-bashing
column24: flag-waving neo-conservative ranting
column25: followed by 200 pages of more flag-waving and China-bashing thinly disguised as a number of battle sequences. It's not completely without its moments (hence the 2 stars) but it's definitely not recommended

But for someone that wants quick and easy advice
column5: this book is certainly not for them. I'm afraid that this book of jargon will make it more confusing.

column1: Caveat - I wasn't exactly expecting to finish PE a die-hard believer.  That said
column2: I was unprepared for how much of my skepticism stemmed from the authors' willingness to believe anything
column3: and mask their suspension of disbelief as objectivity.  According to legend
column4: the US Navy conducted invisibility experiments on one of their ships during WWII.  Not simply invisible
column5: the ship actually teleported from its berth in Philadelphia.  However
column6: the little-understood process played havoc with the crew - even after the experiment's end
column7: some crewmen would "blink" in and out of existence
column8: become frozen in time or catch fire.  One man walked through a wall
column9: never to be seen again.  Of course
column10: the Navy denies the whole thing....  While the legend places the story during the dark days of WWII
column11: the legend itself began in the mid 1950's
column12: with the publication of "The Case for the UFO" by Morris Jessup.  (Aknowledging that Jessup is no scientist
column13: Berlitz & Moore nevertheless refer to him as "Dr. Jessup".)  Believing that propulsion of UFO's (and perhaps future human spacecraft) lay in solving Einstein's "Unified Field Theory"
column14: Jessup encouraged readers to press for research in that area. Jessup's book caught the attention of Carl Allen (AKA Carlos Allende)
column15: who spent the war in the Merchant Marine.  In a series of rambling letters Allen insisted that Einstein had solved UFT
column16: and the solution was successfully used to cloak a USN warship in wartime experiments.  Though claiming to have witnessed the event from deck of a nearby freighter
column17: Allen goes further than detailing his observation - exhaustively describing the travails of the crew
column18: Einstein's seeming retraction of UFT
column19: his admission to Bertrand Russel that UFT was complete but had to be suppressed at least until after WWIII
column20: the identity of one of the chief scientists attached to the project
column21: and that UFT had anything to do with the experiment.  To get his point across
column22: Allen/Allende even forwarded a copy of Jessup's book (heavily annotated with his own theories
column23: many having nothing to do with the Philadelphia Experiment) to the Office of Naval Research.  There it piqued the personal interest of at least 2 officers
column24: and slowly became the story-that-wouldn't-die.  A few years later
column25: a depressed Jessup was found dead in his car.  Allende/Allen became something of a cult celeb
column26: sometimes retracting what he had previously claimed
column27: often warning against the ominous dangers of UFT even as he seemed to beg others to look into it.  Berlitz and Moore piece Allen/Allende together with what are supposed to be other pieces of a puzzle that will prove the Philadelphia Experiment actually occurred.  Instead
column28: the result is far less than the sum of its parts: Berlitz and Moore place far more weight on any of the individual pieces than common sense would allow
column29: and they find a better fit between the different pieces than you'd get in a jigsaw puzzle.  Nothing in PE lacks a more reasonable explanation than the authors can provide.  At the beginning
column30: and towards the end of the book
column31: the authors mention coming in contact with others who claim to have met alleged crewmembers of the ship involved in the experiment - but neither name nor any other convincing corroborating information comes out (Allende at least included his Merchant Marine ID in his letters).  The authors add to the puzzle
column32: but never actually establish that the Philadelphia Experiment actually occurred.  An anonymous radar scientist
column33: who doesn't claim to have worked on the project
column34: clairifies how events would have had to occurr if the legend were true.  Another scientist - given a psuedonym because it would upset "the status quo" - describes wartime discussions on a project that we're supposed to believe developed into the Philadelphia Experiment.  Named "Rinehart" after a similar character in the novel "Thin Air" (a thriller inspired by the legend) the doctor describes discussions but never mentions witnessing the experiment
column35: nor any discussions of its aftermath - obvious details for such a pivotal figure.  "Rinehart" never even mentions Allende
column36: even though it had been Allende's letters that clued the authors into Rinehart's existence (under yet another pseudonym).  The authors never explain how they managed to find "Rinehart" - they need to protect his identity even though the government obviously knows who he is
column37: and anybody else would have the same difficulty tracking him down as the authors of this book.  The authors describe how the experiments of another scientist in "electrogravity" never caught on despite their apparent success - suggesting they were suppressed.  Though Allende described reading stories about the Experiment's sailors in Philadelphia newspapers
column38: the only article that could be found is obviously bogus: a xerox of an obviously fabricated article describing a bar-room brawl by sailors who mysteriously vanish -  but no mention of date
column39: newspaper
column40: or the reporter
column41: nor any specific facts in the article about the event
column42: like the name of the bar or those of witnesses.  The authors make the barest efforts to answer the questions they raise
column43: and then merely add more pieces to the puzzle
column44: without explaining how one piece corroborates any others.  Though appearing critical and objective
column45: it's impossible to believe that the authors haven't already settled on the idea that the experiment actually occurred - they explicitly question Allende
column46: yet never express their doubts
column47: let alone attempt to deal with our own.   But what's the danger of that?  I mean
column48: who cares if they can get their readers to believe the legend of the "Philadelphia Experiment".  Unfortunately
column49: "Philadelphia" feeds on our prejudices of secret conspiracies
column50: and relies on our willingness to do so with little prompting - never a positive thing.  Worse
column51: it's not even interesting - barely substantive enough to raise the sort of questions that would make a more critical investigation a stirring story.
